ğŸš¨ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª AFD SURGES TO 26% IN GERMAN POLLS AS MIGRANT RAPE STATS SPARK OUTRAGE

Germany's AfD party just rocketed to 26% in the latest polls, making it the country's top political force for the first time ever. 

Experts point to the ruling coalition's endless squabbles under Chancellor Merz as a big driver, plus AfD ramping up its bold talk and internal shakeups. 

At the same time, fresh BKA crime data is blowing up: 

Islamic migrants from Afghanistan and Africa are linked to gang rape suspects at rates way higher than locals, Afghans at 41 per million residents, Africans at 23, other foreigners at 3, versus just 0.6 for Germans.  

That's up to 70x the rate, and folks are asking why Germany keeps rolling out the welcome mat despite the risks.

The migrant crisis, loaded with crime concerns like these gang rape disparities, is straight-up mobilizing voters toward AfD. 

Frustrated Germans see the government fumbling immigration, and AfD's tough stance on borders and security is pulling in support from all sides, turning public anger into poll gains.

Source: Anadolu Agency, @amuse, BKA

retweet.text:
ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ TESLA MODEL Y FALLS OFF 800-METER CLIFF IN CHINA... DRIVER WALKS AWAY

This is absolutely insane.

A Tesla Model Y plunged off an approximately 800-meter cliff in China, tumbling down a mountainside. 

The vehicle was completely destroyed, windows shattered, body mangled beyond recognition.

But the A- and B-pillars held. 

The passenger cabin didn't collapse. 

The battery didn't ignite.

The driver suffered only minor injuries.

Rescue crews had to dismantle the wreckage to recover the vehicle. 

Local reports are calling it a "miracle of survival."

This is what happens when a car is engineered with safety as a priority, not an afterthought. 

Tesla's rigid structural design and low center of gravity from the battery placement aren't just marketing points. 

They're the reason this driver is alive.

800 meters is over 2,600 feet. 

That's not a fender bender. 

That's falling off a mountain.

Most vehicles would have become a coffin. 

The Model Y became a survival pod.

Source: @elonmusk / @ray4tesla

retweet.text:
My friendâ€™s cousin recently went out in Milan and ended up at an afterparty.

What began as a normal night quickly turned into a nightmare. A group of Somalis held him against his will, took all of his belongings, and threatened him. They forced him to log into his accounts and transfer all of his money and cryptocurrency.

He was threatened with knives and guns and genuinely believed he was going to die. In the end, he fought back and managed to escape, knowing they might kill him, but feeling it was his only chance.

I have never heard of something remotely like this happening to someone in my social sphere before third-world mass immigration to Europe.

quoted.text:
This is the most fun moment to be a developer in years. 

The AI tools are imperfect, the patterns are still emerging, and there's genuine room for experimentation. Roll up your sleeves and build something. The earthquake is further opening up what's possible.

The best news about this new layer: traditional engineering skills are more valuable than ever, not less. It helps us minimize shipping slop.

Developers who already invested in CI/CD, testing, documentation, and code review are having the most success with AI tools. These "boring" foundations are accelerators. They turn agents from chaos generators into productivity multipliers.

The real opportunity is learning to work at a different altitude. Instead of typing syntax, we're reviewing implementations, catching edge cases, and shipping features in hours that used to take days. That's genuinely exciting.

Yes, there's a learning curve. Understanding how to provide context, iterate on plans, and review AI-generated code quickly takes practice. But this is learnable through doing - build small tools, review everything, develop intuition through repetition.

The multiplier potential is real when you combine AI speed with engineering judgment. We're not replacing coding skills but we're finally able to focus them on the interesting problems while delegating the tedious parts.

quoted.text: I've never felt this much behind as a programmer. The profession is being dramatically refactored as the bits contributed by the programmer are increasingly sparse and between. I have a sense that I could be 10X more powerful if I just properly string together what has become available over the last ~year and a failure to claim the boost feels decidedly like skill issue. There's a new programmable layer of abstraction to master (in addition to the usual layers below) involving agents, subagents, their prompts, contexts, memory, modes, permissions, tools, plugins, skills, hooks, MCP, LSP, slash commands, workflows, IDE integrations, and a need to build an all-encompassing mental model for strengths and pitfalls of fundamentally stochastic, fallible, unintelligible and changing entities suddenly intermingled with what used to be good old fashioned engineering. Clearly some powerful alien tool was handed around except it comes with no manual and everyone has to figure out how to hold it and operate it, while the resulting magnitude 9 earthquake is rocking the profession. Roll up your sleeves to not fall behind.

RT @karpathy: Agency > Intelligence

I had this intuitively wrong for decades, I think due to a pervasive cultural veneration of intelligenâ€¦

retweet.text:
Agency > Intelligence

I had this intuitively wrong for decades, I think due to a pervasive cultural veneration of intelligence, various entertainment/media, obsession with IQ etc. Agency is significantly more powerful and significantly more scarce. Are you hiring for agency? Are we educating for agency? Are you acting as if you had 10X agency?

Grok explanation is ~close:

â€œAgency, as a personality trait, refers to an individual's capacity to take initiative, make decisions, and exert control over their actions and environment. Itâ€™s about being proactive rather than reactiveâ€”someone with high agency doesnâ€™t just let life happen to them; they shape it. Think of it as a blend of self-efficacy, determination, and a sense of ownership over oneâ€™s path.

People with strong agency tend to set goals and pursue them with confidence, even in the face of obstacles. Theyâ€™re the type to say, â€œIâ€™ll figure it out,â€ and then actually do it. On the flip side, someone low in agency might feel more like a passenger in their own life, waiting for external forcesâ€”like luck, other people, or circumstancesâ€”to dictate what happens next.

Itâ€™s not quite the same as assertiveness or ambition, though it can overlap. Agency is quieter, more internalâ€”itâ€™s the belief that you *can* act, paired with the will to follow through. Psychologists often tie it to concepts like locus of control: high-agency folks lean toward an internal locus, feeling they steer their fate, while low-agency folks might lean external, seeing life as something that happens *to* them.â€

Most of it was distracted driving: texting, drinking, zoning out.

Tesla's FSD cuts down those crashes by over 80%, because it doesnâ€™t get drunk, tired or stare at TikTok instead of the road.

Some crashes are still possible, but FSD watches everything all the time. Humans donâ€™t.

Their data shows it could eliminate 30% to 44% of distracted driving crashes.

If these numbers hold up, not using it sounds way more dangerous than using it.

Source: @Tesla  @SawyerMerritt

The easy ability to call @grok on twitter is probably the biggest thing after community notes that has been positive for the truth-friendliness of this platform.

The fact that you don't see ahead of time how grok will respond is key here - I've seen many situations where someone calls on grok expecting their crazy political belief to be confirmed and grok comes along and rugs them.

retweet.text:
If your CEO is literally riding in the passenger seat while the car drives itself around a major U.S. city, with no safety monitor in the vehicle, thatâ€™s about as bullish of a signal you can send to the market that autonomy is here and Tesla has solved it.

This is Elon Musk, in Austin, letting Teslaâ€™s AI do 100% of the work, confident enough in the technology to remove the last human supervision inside the vehicle.

What honesty makes this moment special to me is how long itâ€™s been coming.

Tesla first talked about full autonomy back in 2016, when FSD was introduced as a long-term software promise. Since then, weâ€™ve had
â€¢ years of real world data collection
â€¢ multiple hardware generations
â€¢ vision only going against industry consensus of LiDAR
â€¢ endless doubt and skepticism, delays, and â€œitâ€™ll never workâ€ headlines

This is nearly a decade of hard work and intelligent iterations to reach this moment.

When the person with the most to lose is willing to trust the system with his own life, this debate now ends overnight. Weâ€™ve been waiting for this day for almost 10 yearsâ€¦ 

Elon may not always be on time, may be very optimistic at times, but he and his team always delivers. 

Damn, it feels good to be a retail Tesla investor.

What is @grok? It is deep empathy! 

From Heinleinâ€™s Stranger in a Strange Land:

Grok means "identically equal". The human clichÃ© "This hurts me worse than it does you" has a distinctly Martian flavor. The Martian seems to know instinctively what we learned painfully from modern physics, that observer acts with observed through the process of observation. Grokmeans to understand so thoroughly that the observer becomes a part of the observedÂ â€” to merge, blend, intermarry, lose identity in group experience. It means almost everything that we mean by religion, philosophy, and science and it means as little to us as color does to a blind man.

tweets.text: RT @Teslaconomics: Iâ€™ve researched so many founders and CEOs in my lifetime bc itâ€™s the most important thing when it comes to investing. Anâ€¦

retweet.text:
Iâ€™ve researched so many founders and CEOs in my lifetime bc itâ€™s the most important thing when it comes to investing. And Iâ€™ve realized more and more that the difference between Elon and most founders or CEOs is very simple and super rare.

Many CEOs lead and give orders from an ivory tower, while Elon is always and willing to fight in the trenches with his people. While many CEOs give orders from a far, Elon is hands on with everything at Tesla. Heâ€™s on the factory floor. In the engineering and design room. In uncomfortable situations and makes the tough decisions. On top of this, he directly uses the products him and the team builds first hand and is wiling to put his heath and life at risk in doing so.

I remember when he was willing to risk arrest during COVID rather than shut down what his team was fighting to build. He put his own freedom on the line because he believed in the mission and in the people behind it.

â€œTesla is restarting production today against Alameda County rules. I will be on the line with everyone else. If anyone is arrested, I ask that it only be me.â€ - Elon Musk

This kind of leadership is different.

When your CEO is willing to take the hits for the team, sleep on the factory floor, and personally stand in front of the fire, it creates trust that he will NEVER let Tesla fail.

Real leaders donâ€™t hide, they step forward, as one.

quoted.text:
Here is one surprisingly elegant equivalent reformulation of the Riemann Hypothesis: Let B be the pointwise maximal function on [0,1] satisfying B(0) = B(1) = 0 and 2B((x+y)/2) â‰¤ B(x) + B(y) + |x - y| for all x and y in [0,1]. Extend it periodically to all the real line.

As Grok correctly notes, this is Takagi function (or blancmange curve), with a fractal-like graph. It is continuous, nowhere differentiable, and less well-known than the Weierstrass function.
 
This function also emerged recently (and independently) in a joint work https://t.co/pgJw9MaEA1  with my student, Natanael Alpay, as a sharp lower bound for the L^1 norm of the square function applied to indicator functions of sets. I was unaware at the time that it is known as the Takagi function or of its connection to the Riemann Hypothesis. Large language models will undoubtedly accelerate scientific discoveries by forging connections across diverse fields of science.

RT @TeslaLarry: It seems this post went over the heads of some of the socialists, so let me put it as simply as possible:
1. If the US hadâ€¦

retweet.text:
It seems this post went over the heads of some of the socialists, so let me put it as simply as possible:
1. If the US had not "given" (using Socialist jargon here) Musk $38b, they would have had to have "given" Boeing, Lockheed Martin and other "Aerospace" companies $78b (and they probably would not have been able to have got delivery the products & services in time, or ever, anyway).
2. Elon Musk's companies deliver between $100b to $140b of taxes and added value to the US and it's citizens every year (more than the GDP of a small state), and these contributions are growing faster than the US economy every year.
3. To spell it out to the unbelievers, the US (and particularly Elon's 140,000 employees) is earning an enormous return from Elon Musk's wealth.

quoted.text:
Lot of posts copying the likes of @BernieSanders @SenWarren and @AOC calling for more taxes on Billionaire @elonmusk, forgetting that in 2021 he paid a 53% rate of tax totaling $11b. They all repeat the claim that his company has received benefits of $38b from the US Government.  
Let's look at his REAL economic impact to the U.S. It's mind blowing.
Muskâ€™s ventures currently contribute $100â€“140B in annual GDP impact, or roughly 0.4% of total U.S. GDP. And growing faster â€“ considerably faster â€“ than the US economy, promising even greater contributions in the future.
Thatâ€™s more annual contribution to US GDP than entire annual GDP of smaller U.S. states, like West Virginia (~$108 billion, 0.37%) or Hawaii (~$116 billion, 0.40%). And growing faster.
On top of that NASA and US Department of War have cumulatively saved over $40 billion as a direct result of SpaceX delivering a reduction in the cost of delivery of launch and communication services over traditional vendors. SO much for Musk Companies having "received" $38b. In other words, had the U.S. not paid Musk companies $38b, then the US would have had to spend $78b with competitors (and possibly then not received a delivery of the goods ordered! Boeing, looking at you.) Not to mention that Starlink practically saved Ukraine from being overrun in the early days of the Russian invasion.
Seems we are all, all Americans - and citizens of the world in fact - benefiting from the growth of Muskâ€™s net worth. Here are the numbers:
Please post this in response to every post you see bleating about Musk being a billionaire or trillionaire and how its so terrible.

tweets.text:
RT @BLKMDL3: 10 hours into Tesla FSD v14.2.2 and here are my thoughts:

Zero lane change hesitation at all. Extremely refined, excellent laâ€¦

retweet.text:
10 hours into Tesla FSD v14.2.2 and here are my thoughts:

Zero lane change hesitation at all. Extremely refined, excellent lane choices and some parking improvements are a few things to note. 

Really stoked about the lane changes on this build. There is ZERO lane indecisiveness, no hesitation, no stuttering. Nothing. I had never really seen much before, but this build you can tell its decision making process is much quicker and it commits. 

Mad Max mode is definitely mad again and I love it. Seems even quicker than v14.2.1.25 which was an improvement, but the lane changes + choices are better now. Hurry mode seems quicker on the highways and larger roads than before and very close to Mad Max, it was perfect before on v14.2.1.25. 

The new addition on the release notes for arrival pin being adjusted based on arrival option works. It changes the route based on if youâ€™re going curbside, or to the lot or street parking. It behaved that way before usually but now itâ€™s visualized. 

Parking is improved and impressive this build. Every single spot I parked in, it performed excellent. Centered in the lines, quick one and done parking jobs and they were great, improvement over early v14.2 builds. In parking garages, it now pulls up exactly at the ticket dispenser where in earlier v14.2 builds it would stop 9 inches short like I mentioned in previous v14.2+ build reviews. Thatâ€™s fixed and worked great- couldnâ€™t have asked for it to be any better. Perfect distance and approach- will do a lot more of this testing tomorrow. 

Canyon roads were insanely impressive. Did the snake 3 times which is a super narrow and twisty road and each time it performed great. Speeds were good, took the proper lines and even accelerated out of corners very well. These were all in the dark too very late at night- will post some more videos of it. 

Stop and go traffic performance in rush hour was awesome as before, with some added notes for how well it waited to enter an intersection if there was stopped traffic on the other side. It waited 3/3 lights I encountered where if it went and the light changed, it would be sticking into traffic so it didnâ€™t go. Exactly like a human wouldnâ€™t but the car judged it better than I did. One time it creeped a bit slow, but other than that fine since. Saw one instance of red hands but before I could react, it had already recovered itself. 

Still so impressed with how well it handles lane splitting motorcycles. It sees them approaching before I even do, and moves over just enough to be courteous to the rider as well as the car or shoulder next to me. Nice touch, and glad to see it perform well. 

One thing I noticed is how smooth its steering inputs always are. It just takes corners with such precision and smoothness that no human could ever come close to it. Especially noticeable on twisty roads- it drives better than almost every human on them. And I encountered a power outage tonight and the car still drove perfectly even with pitch black around. 

Overall, loving what Iâ€™m seeing with this build. Will report back in the day time with more but I am going to head home to get some sleep. 

Another huge thank you to all the magicians @Tesla_AI for working so hard during the holiday season to get these updates out.

I was very late to own a Tesla but among the earliest to try out FSD v14.  It's perhaps the first time I experience an AI that passes the Physical Turing Test: after a long day at work, you press a button, lay back, and couldn't tell if a neural net or a human drove you home.

Despite knowing exactly how robot learning works, I still find it magical watching the steering wheel turn by itself. 

First it feels surreal, next it becomes routine. Then, like the smartphone, taking it away actively hurts. This is how humanity gets rewired and glued to god-like technologies.

retweet.text:
No the left wasnâ€™t just "annoying on Twitter for a few years" â€” they did the following:

â€¢ Created vast bureaucratic systems staffed by their activists to discriminate against White men in both university admissions and corporate America

â€¢ Institutionalized anti-White training in both the workplace and all of education

â€¢ Normalized a racial hierarchy in grade schools and above via white privilege trainings and DEI grading systems that racially discriminate

â€¢ They flooded every form of media with content that demonized "Whiteness" and White men specifically, with a coordinated effort to reduce the amount of positive White male role models and White relationships in ads, on shows and in movies while increasing the sexual hedonism promoted to kidsâ€” this effort also included a racial tilt in news coverage to always note the skin color of White offenders while concealing the skin color of minority offenders

â€¢ They used our tax dollars to pay for DEI policies, trainings and practices that explicitly pushed a racist narrative against Whites

â€¢ They lowered standards in medical schools and other life altering institutions to force less White people into those professions, a move that will cost people their lives in years to come

â€¢ They created social norms through all of this to make Whites fearful of complaining about the blatant discrimination they faced

And thatâ€™s only a partial list. The past decade was an outright operation to discriminate against Whites through left wing policy, and now theyâ€™re trying to pretend it was a few woke scolds on Twitter. It wasnâ€™t and we will never let this lie take root. I say all of this as a Latino who had actual privilege by being a minority during that time period. If I can recognize this then surely you should be able to. 

It can never happen again and the people who were responsible should never see an ounce of power again. Not even as a dogcatcher. Period.

Lot of posts copying the likes of @BernieSanders @SenWarren and @AOC calling for more taxes on Billionaire @elonmusk, forgetting that in 2021 he paid a 53% rate of tax totaling $11b. They all repeat the claim that his company has received benefits of $38b from the US Government.  
Let's look at his REAL economic impact to the U.S. It's mind blowing.
Muskâ€™s ventures currently contribute $100â€“140B in annual GDP impact, or roughly 0.4% of total U.S. GDP. And growing faster â€“ considerably faster â€“ than the US economy, promising even greater contributions in the future.
Thatâ€™s more annual contribution to US GDP than entire annual GDP of smaller U.S. states, like West Virginia (~$108 billion, 0.37%) or Hawaii (~$116 billion, 0.40%). And growing faster.
On top of that NASA and US Department of War have cumulatively saved over $40 billion as a direct result of SpaceX delivering a reduction in the cost of delivery of launch and communication services over traditional vendors. SO much for Musk Companies having "received" $38b. In other words, had the U.S. not paid Musk companies $38b, then the US would have had to spend $78b with competitors (and possibly then not received a delivery of the goods ordered! Boeing, looking at you.) Not to mention that Starlink practically saved Ukraine from being overrun in the early days of the Russian invasion.
Seems we are all, all Americans - and citizens of the world in fact - benefiting from the growth of Muskâ€™s net worth. Here are the numbers:
Please post this in response to every post you see bleating about Musk being a billionaire or trillionaire and how its so terrible.
